results.content: Worst course of wThe worst web design course I've ever seen. You won't learn anything and you'll spend the practice copying code you don't know it does. Luckily I learned programming and web design by other means, because of this course I can only save the practice as an exercise to review my knowledge, replicate it for the pleasure of practicing. Since nowadays I dedicate myself more to programming than to web layout, practical exercises such as replicating websites go very well to keep my knowledge of css, boostrap, etc. up to date. But if you start from scratch, with this course you will be lost if you think that only by watching it you can replicate a website without any help. There are much better courses than this.

results.content: Loved this course! It covered several practical things that I had been wanting to learn, and I used the information to build a website of my own. Teacher is great. Highly recommend!

results.content:
The course only requires of you to have a text editor but that won't cut it. You do need to have HTML, CSS and JS knowledge unless you want to use this course as a cookbook. In that case, it will serve you well. Although the instructor explains HTML and CSS in greater detail than JS, he still uses parts that weren't covered or, at least, talked about in previous lessons. I regard this course as practice after you've learned the web trinity and you want to practice it on a webpage. 

If you've never touched JavaScript, the code you type will do its thing but you won't know why it is used or how it actually works. Directing students to job sites like Upwork or Freelancer with only the knowledge gathered during this course is a great mistake unless you have decided to do some background reading about HTML, CSS and JS on MDN, W3Schools or another reference site, and made a couple of websites yourself. The most useful part for me in this course was figuring out how to use Bootstrap framework.
results.content_html:
The course only requires of you to have a text editor but that won't cut it. You do need to have HTML, CSS and JS knowledge unless you want to use this course as a cookbook. In that case, it will serve you well. Although the instructor explains HTML and CSS in greater detail than JS, he still uses parts that weren't covered or, at least, talked about in previous lessons. I regard this course as practice after you've learned the web trinity and you want to practice it on a webpage.

If you've never touched JavaScript, the code you type will do its thing but you won't know why it is used or how it actually works. Directing students to job sites like Upwork or Freelancer with only the knowledge gathered during this course is a great mistake unless you have decided to do some background reading about HTML, CSS and JS on MDN, W3Schools or another reference site, and made a couple of websites yourself. The most useful part for me in this course was figuring out how to use Bootstrap framework.
